newsitem.title: GERMANY: BUBA'S KOEPNICK EXPECTS EIGHT TO MEET EMU TARGET.
newsitem.headline: BUBA'S KOEPNICK EXPECTS EIGHT TO MEET EMU TARGET.

text.p: Hans-Juergen Koebnick, Rhineland-Pfalz/Saarland central bank president and Bundesbank council-member, said he expects up to eight European countries to qualify for currency union by January 1, 1999.

Speaking in a radio interview with Saarland Radio on Saturday, Koebnick said he expected Germany, France, Luxembourg, Belgium and the Netherlands to meet requirements for European Monetary Union in 1997.
"We then have to see if Ireland or Finland or Austria are still there at that time," Koebnick said, adding that 1997 would be a decisive year for currency union.
Koebnick said he thought the introduction of the Euro was becoming "increasingly likely."
Koebnick was positive on the development of price stability in Europe, but said fiscal criteria needed more attention and called for a stability plan to regulate budgetary deficits and debt.
"Correct economic and financial behaviour" was necessary, Koebnick said.
